dfischer.utils

Class DNSTranslationTable

  • java.lang.Object
    • dfischer.utils.DNSTranslationTable

  • public class DNSTranslationTable
extends java.lang.Object
    A table that translates a DNS name to another DNS name.

    Note 1: It could be needed that TLS SNI (Server Name Indication) must be disabled if a DNS translation table is used.
    Note 2: The HTTP request header field "Host" is not updated, so it might happen that you call the Web server with the wrong host name.

    See Also:
    DNSCache, HttpSocketPool.setHintUseSNI(boolean)

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      DNSTranslationTable()
      Empty constructor for object transfer.
      DNSTranslationTable(java.io.File dnsTranslationFile)
      Deprecated. 
      since V5.4-K, does not support encrypted DNS translation file. Create a new instance which is initialized with the content of a DNS translation file. The DNS translation file is a text file that contains on each line a translation between two DNS names. If the first DNS name in the file match to the DNS name that is passed to the resolver then the second DNS name is used to resolve the IP address. The first DNS name can also contain one or more wildcard characters ('*' = wildcard for multiple characters, '?' = wildcard for single character). Lines or a part of a line can be commented out by using the hash char '#'.

      DNS translation file example: 

       www.proxy*sniffer.com  www.d-fischer.com # comment
 #comment
 www.mutong.com www.d-fischer.com
 mail?.google.com       mail.google.com
      Note 1: It could be needed that TLS SNI (Server Name Indication) must be disabled if a DNS translation table is used.
      Note 2: The HTTP request header field "Host" is not updated, so it might happen that you call the Web server with the wrong host name.
      DNSTranslationTable(java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> translationMap)
      Create a new instance which is initialized with a hash map that contains as keys DNS names which are translated to the value = a second DNS name: that is used to resolve the IP address.
      DNSTranslationTable(SymmetricEncryptContext decryptContext, java.io.File dnsTranslationFile)
      Create a new instance which is initialized with the content of a DNS translation file.

      • DNSTranslationTable

        public DNSTranslationTable(SymmetricEncryptContext decryptContext,
                   java.io.File dnsTranslationFile)
                    throws java.io.IOException
        Create a new instance which is initialized with the content of a DNS translation file. The DNS translation file is a text file that contains on each line a translation between two DNS names. If the first DNS name in the file match to the DNS name that is passed to the resolver then the second DNS name is used to resolve the IP address. The first DNS name can also contain one or more wildcard characters ('*' = wildcard for multiple characters, '?' = wildcard for single character). Lines or a part of a line can be commented out by using the hash char '#'.

        DNS translation file example: 

         www.proxy*sniffer.com  www.d-fischer.com # comment
 #comment
 www.mutong.com www.d-fischer.com
 mail?.google.com       mail.google.com
        Note 1: It could be needed that TLS SNI (Server Name Indication) must be disabled if a DNS translation table is used.
        Note 2: The HTTP request header field "Host" is not updated, so it might happen that you call the Web server with the wrong host name.
        Parameters:
        decryptContext - the context to decrypt the file, or null if the file is not encrypted
        dnsTranslationFile - the DNS translation file
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        Since:
        V5.4-K
        See Also:
        translate(String), HttpSocketPool.setHintUseSNI(boolean)

      • DNSTranslationTable

        public DNSTranslationTable(java.io.File dnsTranslationFile)
                    throws java.io.IOException
        Deprecated. since V5.4-K, does not support encrypted DNS translation file. Create a new instance which is initialized with the content of a DNS translation file. The DNS translation file is a text file that contains on each line a translation between two DNS names. If the first DNS name in the file match to the DNS name that is passed to the resolver then the second DNS name is used to resolve the IP address. The first DNS name can also contain one or more wildcard characters ('*' = wildcard for multiple characters, '?' = wildcard for single character). Lines or a part of a line can be commented out by using the hash char '#'.

        DNS translation file example: 

         www.proxy*sniffer.com  www.d-fischer.com # comment
 #comment
 www.mutong.com www.d-fischer.com
 mail?.google.com       mail.google.com
        Note 1: It could be needed that TLS SNI (Server Name Indication) must be disabled if a DNS translation table is used.
        Note 2: The HTTP request header field "Host" is not updated, so it might happen that you call the Web server with the wrong host name.
        Parameters:
        dnsTranslationFile - the DNS translation file
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        See Also:
        translate(String), HttpSocketPool.setHintUseSNI(boolean)

      • DNSTranslationTable

        public DNSTranslationTable(java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> translationMap)
        Create a new instance which is initialized with a hash map that contains as keys DNS names which are translated to the value = a second DNS name: that is used to resolve the IP address. The keys can also contain one or more wildcard characters ('*' = wildcard for multiple characters, '?' = wildcard for single character).

        Note 1: It could be needed that TLS SNI (Server Name Indication) must be disabled if a DNS translation table is used.
        Note 2: The HTTP request header field "Host" is not updated, so it might happen that you call the Web server with the wrong host name.

        Parameters:
        translationMap - the hash map with key = DNS name (match key for resolver) and value = DNS name (used to resolve the IP address)
        See Also:
        translate(String), HttpSocketPool.setHintUseSNI(boolean)

      • getDNSTranslationFile

        public java.io.File getDNSTranslationFile()
        Get the DNS translation file (context information only).
        Returns:
        the DNS translation file, or null if no such data are available

      • getTranslationMap

        public java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> getTranslationMap()
        Get the DNS translation table in form of a hash map.
        Returns:
        a hash map with key = first DNS name and value = second DNS name

        Dump all table data to stdout.

        public java.lang.String translate(java.lang.String resolverDNSName)
        Translate a DNS name to another DNS name.
        Parameters:
        resolverDNSName - the DNS name to translate to another DNS name
        Returns:
        the translated DNS name, or null if no translation was made
